TPR blog post on managing systemic risks The latest blog post from the Pensions Regulator (TPR) highlights the importance of managing systemic risks, including climate change, nature loss and broader ESG factors, as "a core part" of effective scheme governance and trustees' fiduciary responsibilities. TPR encourages schemes to use the Taskforce on Nature-related Financial Disclosures (TNFD) resources to inform their thinking. The blog post includes questions trustees should ask themselves to help assess how well equipped they are in this area. + A&O SHEARMAN COMMISSION NOT IMPOSSIBLE: NO BRIBERY OR FIDUCIARY BREACH IN CAR FINANCE COMMISSION CASE

In a significant decision for the car finance industry, the UK Supreme Court has decided that lenders who financed car loans were not liable to their customers for bribery for failing to obtain their informed consent to commission payments made by the lenders to the dealers arranging the finance.

The court determined that, for the tort of bribery to be committed, the recipient of the bribe must be a fiduciary, and the dealers did not owe a fiduciary duty to their customers. For the same reason, the lenders had not dishonestly assisted in a breach of fiduciary duty by the dealers.

In relation to one customer, however, liability did arise on the basis there was an unfair relationship between the customer and lender for the purposes of the Consumer Credit Act 1974.

The decision largely overturns the Court of Appeal's controversial judgment from last autumn which held that lenders financing car loans could be liable in such cases.

WhiteFiber owns high-performance computing data centers and provides cloud services to customers. Its vertically integrated model combines specialized colocation, hosting and cloud services engineered to maximize performance, efficiency and margin for generative AI workloads.

+ WHITE & CASE PARTNER ON USING LEGAL KNOWLEDGE AS A SPRINGBOARD

In a Q&A with International Financial Law Review as part of its "Five minutes with" series, White & Case partner Jessica Chen discussed her practice and career.

When providing an overview of her work, Jessica explained: "I help companies raise capital, mainly using their equity, in order to fund initiatives that help the company grow." She noted that she spends much of her days working with clients and colleagues across Europe and Asia, also emphasizing the support she receives from the "brilliant associates" she works alongside.

"The most exciting aspect is that each day is different, and I never know what new issues will come my way," Jessica said, adding that the Firm is "at the forefront of structuring new ways of doing things and figuring out how it works."

While Jessica noted the importance of understanding the rules as a lawyer, she argues that "a truly great lawyer then uses that knowledge as a springboard."

Source: Company Website

+ WHITE & CASE ADVISES FOTOWATIO RENEWABLE VENTURES (FRV) AUSTRALIA ON DEVELOPMENT AND FINANCING OF GNARWARRE BATTERY ENERGY STORAGE SYSTEM

Global law firmWhite & Case LLP has advised Fotowatio Renewable Ventures (FRV) Australia on the development and financing of the 250 MW/500 MWh Gnarwarre battery energy storage system (BESS), near Geelong in the state of Victoria.

"FRVAustralia successfully leveraged its existing portfolio financing facility to finance the construction of the Gnarwarre BESS," said White & Case partner Candice Ota, who co-led the Firm's deal team. "Portfolio financing facilities can provide developers with greater flexibility to fund their development pipeline."

The stand-alone BESS project includes grid forming inverters and will assist the national electrical network to compensate for times of peak demand and energy oversupply.

The Gnarwarre BESS is FRVAustralia's largest battery to date and was financed under its A$1.2 billion portfolio financing facility, which was established in July 2024. The loan facility was provided by a syndicate of five financial institutions: Westpac Banking Corporation, United Overseas Bank, Intesa Sanpaolo, KfW IPEX-Bank and Export Development Canada. The project's funding also includes grant funding from the Australian Renewable Energy Agency (ARENA), which awarded a A$15 million grant under its Large Scale Battery Storage Funding Round.

+ WHITE & CASE SECURES DISMISSAL OF DEUTSCHE BAHN'S STUTTGART 21 COST OVERRUN LAWSUIT FOR STATE OF BADEN-W RTTEMBERG

Global law firmWhite & Case LLP has secured a victory for the State of Baden-Wurttemberg in the Administrative Court of Appeal of Baden-Wurttemberg, which rejected Deutsche Bahn's request to appeal a 2024 judgment by the Stuttgart Administrative Court related to the financing of the Stuttgart 21 project.

"At no point did the State of Baden-Wurttemberg assume any obligation to cover the cost overruns of the Stuttgart 21 project," said White & Case partner Henning Berger, who led the team which achieved the dismissals before both the Stuttgart Administrative Court and the Administrative Court of Appeal of Baden-Wurttemberg. "The state only made specific financial contributions under public subsidy law, as clearly and unambiguously defined in the financing agreement. The Administrative Court of Appeal has now confirmed this in its decision."

The Stuttgart Administrative Court had dismissed Deutsche Bahn's claim for approximately EUR7 billion in additional project costs against the State of Baden-Wurttemberg and other defendants relating to the financing of the Stuttgart 21 project. The decision of the Administrative Court of Appeal of Baden-Wurttemberg, which is final and cannot be appealed, establishes the Stuttgart Administrative Court's ruling as legally binding and definitively establishes that the State of Baden-Wurttemberg is not responsible for covering the significant cost overruns of the Stuttgart 21 project. Neither the so-called 'negotiation clause' in the Stuttgart 21 financing agreement, nor any other contractual or statutory basis, creates an obligation for the state to bear these additional costs in whole or in part

AECOM Latest Earnings Highlights

Highlights of the Latest Earnings Report Q2 Fiscal 2025

AECOM posted adjusted earnings per share (EPS) of $1.25, exceeding forecasts by 8.7% and marking a 20% increase compared to the previous year.

Revenues experienced a decline year-over-year, though net service revenues (NSR) rose by 1%, reaching $742 million, supported by strong performance in the United Kingdom and Hong Kong markets.

Operating cash flow significantly increased by 102% to $191 million, while adjusted free cash flow surged by 141% to $178 million.

The company's total backlog climbed to $17.78 billion, compared to $17.38 billion during the same period last year, securing strong future revenue opportunities.

Guidance for fiscal 2025 was raised, with adjusted EPS projected between $5.10 and $5.20 and adjusted EBITDA between $1.180 and $1.210 billion, alongside NSR growth expectations of 5-8%.

Adjusted EBITDA margins are anticipated to improve by 30 basis points, ranging from 16.1% to 16.3%, with over 100% conversion from adjusted net income to free cash flow expected.

International revenues dropped by 3% to $875 million; however, operational improvements contributed to a margin expansion of 10 basis points, reaching 11.1%.

Analyst Commentary

Strong Margin Expansion and Operational Efficiency

Observers highlight AECOM's ongoing progress towards achieving its goal of a 17%-plus margin. This success is attributed to a strategic focus on high-margin markets and efficient project execution processes that enhance profitability.

Operational efficiency, supported by disciplined cost management, has enabled reinvestment into high-return initiatives, further strengthening long-term competitiveness.

Robust Cash Flow and Capital Allocation

Exceptional free cash flow growth of 141% underscores the company's healthy financial position. This robust cash flow supports disciplined strategies, including consistent share repurchases and annual dividend growth commitments exceeding 20%.

Resilient Backlog and Pipeline Growth

AECOM's record-breaking backlog of $17.78 billion and a book-to-burn ratio of 1.2x in its design business signify continued demand. The infrastructure and environmental sectors are noted as drivers propelling global growth opportunities.

Exposure to High-Growth Markets

Growth in strategic areas such as transportation, water, and environmental services positions AECOM to leverage rising global investments in sustainable infrastructure. Advancements in AI and digital technologies further highlight avenues for growth in high-demand segments.

Challenges in Revenue Growth and International Markets

Challenges persist as revenues declined year-over-year, with international performance impacted by currency fluctuations and market-specific factors. Nonetheless, the company's focus on organic growth initiatives provides strategic support against these challenges.

Optimism for Long-Term Prospects

Industry-wide optimism underscores AECOM's resilience and alignment with essential global trends such as urbanization and climate change. Its steady earnings growth and ability to mitigate economic uncertainties affirm confidence in its long-term trajectory.

Company Profile

AECOM is recognized as a global leader in infrastructure consulting services, offering comprehensive solutions in planning, design, engineering, construction management, and advisory sectors. The Americas represent its largest source of revenue, driven by transportation and water infrastructure projects involving design and construction management services. International segments also contribute notably to overall performance. Key growth areas include the Water and Environment Advisory business, propelled by the rising demand for sustainable solutions, and transportation design services, fueled by expanding global infrastructure investments. With a focus on high-margin operations and digital technology integration, the company continues solidifying its position as a leader in high-growth markets.

title: Changing the urban landscape
bodyText:
The importance of our outdoor spaces has been realised, and landscape architects are now enjoying their time in the sun.

Landscape architects have grabbed top spot in many of the most significant city-making projects underway across the country, moving up from being brought in after the fact to put a little "parsley around the pig".

Now, instead of merely adding a garnish of greenery in the late stages, they're front and centre, crafting designs that make the most of sites, and ensuring that even high-density developments allow for connections to nature.

That's the case for every major development planned, from plotting new medium-density housing studded with green parks in Sydney to surrounding the new Harbourside Residences at Darling Harbour with trees and open spaces; and from Melbourne's ecological restoration project, the Greenline, to its landscape-led community in Ashburton.

"Landscape architects look at what a city needs and at its topography, as well as taking into account climate change and the need for regenerative projects and for development to be naturepositive," says Jason Cuffe, managing director of Moir Studio, which has just opened an office in Sydney.

"There's a housing crisis, especially in Sydney, and while there's a need for density, we're also looking for quality of amenity, open space and greenery. We don't want just green around the edges."

Moir's projects include Harbourside - where developer Mirvac's Stuart Penklis says landscaping is one of the most important pillars - as well as the Parks for People Program and the Macquarie Street East precinct. Others are the Western Ridges Walk (or Gabrugal Yana) at the Western Sydney Parklands and the Bridges Hill Park Playground at Cessnock in the Hunter Valley.

Planning from the ground up Across the world, landscape architects are at the fore. This year's international landscape architecture conference in Toronto (held by the creatively named Council on Tall Buildings and Urban Habitat) is titled From the Ground Up to show how important it is to start planning on the ground plane.

The global design director of Aspect Studios, Sacha Coles, says that precept should be the first priority, and the buildings are secondary.

"It's ground-up urbanism, looking at everything from the site's geology to its history and social and cultural factors," he says. "We should consider the streets as public spaces so the buildings contribute to the overall space, and, done well, they can be amazing contributors.

"We've seen priorities change dramatically over the past 25 years.

Now, the focus is on the health benefits developments offer, creating biodiversity with regenerative design, transport opportunities to cycle and walk and generous open spaces." Those are the principles of many of the developments he's worked on and is currently engaged with, like Sydney's Darling Square, the refurbishment of Dixon Street in Chinatown, the new fish markets and the cycleway going over the Sydney Harbour Bridge.

Shaping the future Landscape architects are also playing a significant role in Melbourne.

Yazid Ninsalam, associate dean of landscape architecture at RMIT's School of Architecture and Urban Design, says some of those projects include the Greenline, seeing the Yarra (or Birrarung) as a central force in shaping the city, and the new housing development by Mala and Architectus on Markham Avenue in Ashburton. Others include infrastructure as cityshaping, like the Victorian government's Level Crossing Removal Project, which will have taken out 75 crossings by the end of this year; the Royal Park master plan review; and the Arden-Macaulay major urban renewal precinct around the Metro Tunnel station, opening soon in North Melbourne.

"To me, the Arden Central renewal presents an opportunity for landscape architecture to take a leading role in shaping the future of Melbourne," Ninsalam says, referencing the industrial area just north of the CBD, which has faced challenges like contamination, flooding and urban heat.

"A landscape-led approach in rethinking the precinct can demonstrate how public space, ecology and climate resilience are ... fundamental to the city's structure and identity. By integrating green infrastructure with flood management, biodiversity corridors and inclusive public realms, the landscape becomes a vital framework for urban life - cooling the city, fostering community and restoring ecological systems."

City-shaper Urbis also stresses the collaborative role of landscape architects who bring everyone together - such as architects, interior designers and First Nations representatives - to develop the best solutions.

"Together, with a people-centric approach, they can create really inspiring places," says director Mark Kuhne. "They bring nature into cities and build place connections and best performance."

Over 35 health care provisions were included in the One Big Beautiful Bill Act of 2025. These provisions span Medicaid, the Children's Health Insurance Program (CHIP), the Affordable Care Act (ACA) marketplaces, Medicare and commercial insurance. The majority of provisions alter eligibility and spending for health care coverage under Medicaid - and take effect over the next three years. All health provisions of OBBBA will have notable impacts on coverage and care delivery in the U.S. when they take effect. The timeline of effective dates, presented in this Alert, are essential to understanding the cost and coverage impacts.

To comply with the law, states will need to build and operate numerous additional Medicaid and ACA eligibility checks and systems by certain deadlines. Adults who live in states that have expanded Medicaid coverage under the ACA will face narrowed eligibility for Medicaid, and they may need to report monthly their hours of work or community engagement to maintain Medicaid coverage when their state implements this provision. Children of these adults could retain Medicaid eligibility separately - and need to take steps to remain enrolled. Providers will also be closely responding to implementation of the OBBBA as health provisions will impact funding, coverage for their patient populations and the amount of uncompensated care delivered in their communities.

Guidance for fiscal 2025 was raised, with adjusted EPS projected between $5.10 and $5.20 and adjusted EBITDA between $1.180 and $1.210 billion, alongside NSR growth expectations of 5-8%.

Adjusted EBITDA margins are anticipated to improve by 30 basis points, ranging from 16.1% to 16.3%, with over 100% conversion from adjusted net income to free cash flow expected.

International revenues dropped by 3% to $875 million; however, operational improvements contributed to a margin expansion of 10 basis points, reaching 11.1%.

Analyst Commentary

Strong Margin Expansion and Operational Efficiency

Observers highlight AECOM's ongoing progress towards achieving its goal of a 17%-plus margin. This success is attributed to a strategic focus on high-margin markets and efficient project execution processes that enhance profitability.

Operational efficiency, supported by disciplined cost management, has enabled reinvestment into high-return initiatives, further strengthening long-term competitiveness.

Robust Cash Flow and Capital Allocation

Exceptional free cash flow growth of 141% underscores the company's healthy financial position. This robust cash flow supports disciplined strategies, including consistent share repurchases and annual dividend growth commitments exceeding 20%.

Resilient Backlog and Pipeline Growth

AECOM's record-breaking backlog of $17.78 billion and a book-to-burn ratio of 1.2x in its design business signify continued demand. The infrastructure and environmental sectors are noted as drivers propelling global growth opportunities.

Exposure to High-Growth Markets

Growth in strategic areas such as transportation, water, and environmental services positions AECOM to leverage rising global investments in sustainable infrastructure. Advancements in AI and digital technologies further highlight avenues for growth in high-demand segments.

Challenges in Revenue Growth and International Markets

Challenges persist as revenues declined year-over-year, with international performance impacted by currency fluctuations and market-specific factors. Nonetheless, the company's focus on organic growth initiatives provides strategic support against these challenges.

Optimism for Long-Term Prospects

Industry-wide optimism underscores AECOM's resilience and alignment with essential global trends such as urbanization and climate change. Its steady earnings growth and ability to mitigate economic uncertainties affirm confidence in its long-term trajectory.

AECOM is recognized as a global leader in infrastructure consulting services, offering comprehensive solutions in planning, design, engineering, construction management, and advisory sectors. The Americas represent its largest source of revenue, driven by transportation and water infrastructure projects involving design and construction management services. International segments also contribute notably to overall performance. Key growth areas include the Water and Environment Advisory business, propelled by the rising demand for sustainable solutions, and transportation design services, fueled by expanding global infrastructure investments. The Munich District Court in July delivered a first-instance verdict in the Wirecard insolvency,1 allowing holders of convertible notes issued by a Wirecard subsidiary and guaranteed by Wirecard to ultimately recover under two separate claims against the estate (double-dip).

FinCEN, in its earlier announcement, indicated its intent to "revisit the substance" of the Investment Adviser Rule through a future rulemaking process. FinCEN indicated in the Order its intent to propose, through a rulemaking process, a new effective date for the Investment Adviser Rule no earlier than January 1, 2028. August 06: Akin Gump Strauss Hauer Feld LLP: Timeline of Effective Dates of Health Care Provisions of OBBBA is Key to Understanding Impacts

Over 35 health care provisions were included in the One Big Beautiful Bill Act of 2025. These provisions span Medicaid, the Children's Health Insurance Program (CHIP), the Affordable Care Act (ACA) marketplaces, Medicare and commercial insurance. The majority of provisions alter eligibility and spending for health care coverage under Medicaid - and take effect over the next three years. All health provisions of OBBBA will have notable impacts on coverage and care delivery in the U.S. when they take effect. The timeline of effective dates, presented in this Alert, are essential to understanding the cost and coverage impacts.

To comply with the law, states will need to build and operate numerous additional Medicaid and ACA eligibility checks and systems by certain deadlines. Adults who live in states that have expanded Medicaid coverage under the ACA will face narrowed eligibility for Medicaid, and they may need to report monthly their hours of work or community engagement to maintain Medicaid coverage when their state implements this provision. Children of these adults could retain Medicaid eligibility separately - and need to take steps to remain enrolled. Providers will also be closely responding to implementation of the OBBBA as health provisions will impact funding, coverage for their patient populations and the amount of uncompensated care delivered in their communities.

title: Australian miners warn on iron ore oversupply, steel glut
bodyText:
Shanghai | Australian exporters face mounting pressure to go green or risk losing relevance in an oversupplied global market as China demands cleaner, higher-grade iron ore, mining executives have warned.

Geraldine Slattery, president of BHP Australia, said the market dynamics - driven by new ore supply from West Africa - peak or falling steel output and plans by Beijing to move from coal-fired to electric arc steel furnaces and, ultimately, hydrogen, had put miners on notice.

"We are moving into a demand-constrained market, and we're moving into a supply surplus," she told The Australian Financial Review on the sidelines of an industry meeting in Shanghai as part of Prime Minister Anthony Albanese's six-day visit to China.

"As such, there's clearly more authority into the hands of the buyers, and so quality, grade and some of the partnerships we talked about today, in terms of decarbonisation, become important to the relationship."

Top executives from BHP, Rio Tinto, Fortescue and Hancock Prospecting are among scores of business delegates travelling with Albanese as he looks to consolidate a reset in relations between the two countries after a diplomatic freeze that has only recently thawed.

Australia supplies about 60 per cent of China's iron ore, and steel remains the backbone of the world's second-biggest economy, despite a property crash and broader slump in construction.

Monday's meeting, which also included executives from Chinese companies Ansteel Group, Baowu Steel, Hebei Iron and Steel, Hunan Iron and Steel, Shagang Group and Shougang Group, focused on how the two countries could jointly decarbonise steelmaking via hydrogen-powered furnaces, co-operation in research and development and new investment vehicles.

Speaking in Shanghai after the meeting, Albanese brushed aside past trade tensions between the two countries, saying iron ore exports would not be targeted in the same way as lobsters and wine had been during that difficult period.

"I am not concerned," he said.

"Iron ore is different - it's central to both our economies. It's too important," he said, signalling that co-operation on climate and industry could reset the tenor of Australia-China relations after the diplomatic frost.

"This is the first time that Australia's iron ore leaders have met with an Australian prime minister here in China."

Andrew Forrest, Fortescue executive chairman, called for a formal bilateral agreement to promote green iron, warning that artificial intelligence threatened job security in both countries. "Green steel could generate hundreds of thousands of new jobs," he said, "And it protects the ones we already have."

The meeting also underscored the growing convergence between climate ambition and economic strategy. Australia has already legislated a 43 per cent emissions reduction target by 2030 and net zero by 2050.

Australia's iron ore giants have committed billions to green infrastructure in the Pilbara, with BHP, Rio and Fortescue all investing in new smelting techniques, including hydrogen-based and electric blast furnaces, in a bid to stay aligned with the next wave of industrial policy.

Albanese, while saying Canberra was prepared to back the transition with public investment through its National Reconstruction Fund and other equity vehicles, conceded that inward investment from China had slowed to a trickle in recent years.

"We are a country that runs an open economy, and we will look after our national interest," he said. "We depend upon foreign capital, and we welcome investment."

Albanese said the government's role was to provide investment certainty.

But for now, the traditional market structure is shifting in China's favour.

The emergence of China Mineral Resources Group (CMRG) - a state-run buyer established in 2022 - has consolidated Beijing's bargaining power. CMRG now represents more than half of Chinese steelmakers in contract talks with global miners, holds strategic reserves at ports, and has played a role in taming volatile futures markets.

Such is its price-making power that a recent bounce in the iron ore price after a five-month slump has been ascribed to social media reports of a high-level meeting in China this week that has drawn comparisons to the Central Urban Work Conference in 2015.

That meeting was aimed at firing up urban planning and infrastructure development.

The miners themselves are cautious. Fortescue's Andrew Forrest on Monday warned against too much market intervention from the Chinese side, saying artificial price-setting "doesn't work in the long term".

"Intervening in a market is a bit of a sugar hit," he said.

"The most efficient mechanism in the world, like it or not, in the pricing of anything, is the market."

Asked about the impact of US President Donald Trump's tariffs on global trade, Albanese said Canberra would not hit back at the standard 10 per cent levy slapped on Australian exports, nor the sweeping 50 per cent tariff on steel, aluminium and copper shipments.

"We have made it very clear we will not be imposing tariffs back because tariffs are a cost on the country which imposes them," he said.

"We are pursuing diversification of our trading relationships."

+ KIRKLAND & ELLIS: WIRECARD: GERMAN DISTRICT COURT RULES DOUBLE-DIP STRUCTURE IS ENFORCEABLE

The Munich District Court in July delivered a first-instance verdict in the Wirecard insolvency,1 allowing holders of convertible notes issued by a Wirecard subsidiary and guaranteed by Wirecard to ultimately recover under two separate claims against the estate (double-dip).

Such double-dip structures (and similar) have a long legacy in corporate financing transactions and have become particularly topical in the context of liability management transactions as a tool to maximise creditors' recoveries by establishing multiple independent claims against the same pool of collateral assets. Double-dip financings can be used to raise new money, address maturities and reduce interest expense; the structure can incentivise creditor participation, given participating creditors receive "two bites at the apple" without technically priming existing creditors.

+ KIRKLAND & ELLIS: WIRECARD: GERMAN DISTRICT COURT RULES DOUBLE-DIP STRUCTURE IS ENFORCEABLE

The Munich District Court in July delivered a first-instance verdict in the Wirecard insolvency,1 allowing holders of convertible notes issued by a Wirecard subsidiary and guaranteed by Wirecard to ultimately recover under two separate claims against the estate (double-dip).

Such double-dip structures (and similar) have a long legacy in corporate financing transactions and have become particularly topical in the context of liability management transactions as a tool to maximise creditors' recoveries by establishing multiple independent claims against the same pool of collateral assets. Double-dip financings can be used to raise new money, address maturities and reduce interest expense; the structure can incentivise creditor participation, given participating creditors receive "two bites at the apple" without technically priming existing creditors.

AECOM (NYSE:ACM), the NYSE's 8th largest Construction company by market cap, is up 12% Year to Date. There have been changes in analyst ratings and target prices in 2025 - some forward-looking and others that have been after price movements. AECOM Snapshot

AECOM Latest Earnings Highlights

Highlights of the Latest Earnings Report Q2 Fiscal 2025

AECOM posted adjusted earnings per share (EPS) of $1.25, exceeding forecasts by 8.7% and marking a 20% increase compared to the previous year.

Revenues experienced a decline year-over-year, though net service revenues (NSR) rose by 1%, reaching $742 million, supported by strong performance in the United Kingdom and Hong Kong markets.

Operating cash flow significantly increased by 102% to $191 million, while adjusted free cash flow surged by 141% to $178 million.

The company's total backlog climbed to $17.78 billion, compared to $17.38 billion during the same period last year, securing strong future revenue opportunities.

Guidance for fiscal 2025 was raised, with adjusted EPS projected between $5.10 and $5.20 and adjusted EBITDA between $1.180 and $1.210 billion, alongside NSR growth expectations of 5-8%.

Adjusted EBITDA margins are anticipated to improve by 30 basis points, ranging from 16.1% to 16.3%, with over 100% conversion from adjusted net income to free cash flow expected.

International revenues dropped by 3% to $875 million; however, operational improvements contributed to a margin expansion of 10 basis points, reaching 11.1%.

Analyst Commentary

Strong Margin Expansion and Operational Efficiency

Observers highlight AECOM's ongoing progress towards achieving its goal of a 17%-plus margin. This success is attributed to a strategic focus on high-margin markets and efficient project execution processes that enhance profitability.

Operational efficiency, supported by disciplined cost management, has enabled reinvestment into high-return initiatives, further strengthening long-term competitiveness.

Robust Cash Flow and Capital Allocation

Exceptional free cash flow growth of 141% underscores the company's healthy financial position. This robust cash flow supports disciplined strategies, including consistent share repurchases and annual dividend growth commitments exceeding 20%.

Resilient Backlog and Pipeline Growth

AECOM's record-breaking backlog of $17.78 billion and a book-to-burn ratio of 1.2x in its design business signify continued demand. The infrastructure and environmental sectors are noted as drivers propelling global growth opportunities.

Exposure to High-Growth Markets

Growth in strategic areas such as transportation, water, and environmental services positions AECOM to leverage rising global investments in sustainable infrastructure. Advancements in AI and digital technologies further highlight avenues for growth in high-demand segments.

Challenges in Revenue Growth and International Markets

Challenges persist as revenues declined year-over-year, with international performance impacted by currency fluctuations and market-specific factors. Nonetheless, the company's focus on organic growth initiatives provides strategic support against these challenges.

Optimism for Long-Term Prospects

Industry-wide optimism underscores AECOM's resilience and alignment with essential global trends such as urbanization and climate change. Its steady earnings growth and ability to mitigate economic uncertainties affirm confidence in its long-term trajectory.

Company Profile

AECOM is recognized as a global leader in infrastructure consulting services, offering comprehensive solutions in planning, design, engineering, construction management, and advisory sectors. The Americas represent its largest source of revenue, driven by transportation and water infrastructure projects involving design and construction management services. International segments also contribute notably to overall performance. Key growth areas include the Water and Environment Advisory business, propelled by the rising demand for sustainable solutions, and transportation design services, fueled by expanding global infrastructure investments. With a focus on high-margin operations and digital technology integration, the company continues solidifying its position as a leader in high-growth markets.

Jim McCrery, CEO of McCrery Architects, which is part of the project team alongside AECOM, expressed commitment to maintaining the elegance and classical design of the White House. title: Heading into town for a feed could be about to take on a whole new meaning
bodyText:
'(It) could bring added depth and meaning to public spaces.'

Going into town for a feed could take on a whole new meaning when a North-West council's greening strategy takes effect.

Bush foods for the public could join the attractions of Smithton and Stanley after the Circular Head Council adopts a proposed greening strategy.

"Community gardens, edible verges and shared orchards promote food security and encourage connection," council staff said in the draft strategy, which is open for public feedback until June 16.

"Involving Aboriginal knowledge and seasonal bush food planting could bring added depth and meaning to public spaces.

"We can recognise our shared history and culture by drawing on local Aboriginal knowledge to plant natives and bush foods and create yarning circles."

Bush food expert and author Rees Campbell was impressed by the council's thinking.

"A native edible food trail is a fantastic idea," Wynyard-based Ms Campbell said.

"There's quite a few where you can nibble at the whole plant.

"Obviously, you'd have to choose your plants, but it could be done quite easily with quite a range of plants."

She believed bush food could become a visitor attraction for Smithton and Stanley, especially if it had cultural interpretation signage.

Ms Campbell said she knew of more than 150 edible land-based plants in Tasmania.

"If you counted seaweeds, it's into the thousands," she said.

The council's draft said: "In partnership with traditional custodians, greening efforts can also support caring for country, recognising that land, waters, plants, animals and people are deeply interconnected."

"Green spaces can honour Aboriginal seasonal knowledge, provide opportunities for cultural practices like storytelling and gathering and act as places of healing and learning for the whole community.

"Through thoughtful planting and design, we can celebrate both the ancient and evolving relationship between people and place."

The draft said bush foods, herbs and fruiting plants had cultural and practical value.

The council said the strategy would provide a "guiding framework" for including "green infrastructure", such as trees and landscaping, in the future planning, design and maintenance of public spaces in the two towns.

" ... the strategy will help ensure that future projects are well aligned with community needs, climate resilience and sustainable land management," it said.

AECOM (NYSE:ACM) has climbed 15.1% Year To Date. There is uncertainty in the market and it is difficult to predict how economic conditions will be in 2025 and beyond as well as what the impact of those conditions may be on AECOM. However, there are several key reasons why some investors remain bearish on the long-term prospects for AECOM.

Below are some of those key reasons:

- Earnings yield of 2.4% is less attractive compared with the NYSE average earning yield of 4.3%.

- The price-to-earnings ratio of 41.1 indicates overvaluation compared with sector average of 14.4 and market average of 23.5.

- Return on Assets of 4.7% versus sector average of 10.3%.

- Return on Capital Employed of 12.6% versus sector average of 18.5%.

- Total Liabilities/EBITDA of 13.5 is more than 5, this compares unfavourably with the Joseph Piotroski benchmark of 5.

- Net profit margin has averaged 2.6% in the last 3 years. This suggests the company is less profitable with a low margin of safety.

+ KIRKLAND & ELLIS: WIRECARD: GERMAN DISTRICT COURT RULES DOUBLE-DIP STRUCTURE IS ENFORCEABLE

The Munich District Court in July delivered a first-instance verdict in the Wirecard insolvency,1 allowing holders of convertible notes issued by a Wirecard subsidiary and guaranteed by Wirecard to ultimately recover under two separate claims against the estate (double-dip).

Such double-dip structures (and similar) have a long legacy in corporate financing transactions and have become particularly topical in the context of liability management transactions as a tool to maximise creditors' recoveries by establishing multiple independent claims against the same pool of collateral assets. Double-dip financings can be used to raise new money, address maturities and reduce interest expense; the structure can incentivise creditor participation, given participating creditors receive "two bites at the apple" without technically priming existing creditors.

Labor and employment attorney Timothy Taylor was highlighted in a Blooomberg Law article providing an update on the status of nominations for positions at the U.S. Department of Labor (DOL). The U.S. Senate must approve the nominees for DOL leadership roles such as the Solicitor of Labor and Wage and Hour Division leader, and most of the 10 slots have yet to be brought to the floor for a vote. Mr. Taylor noted that though the agency can continue pushing forth policy positions and proposing or rescinding rules, lacking confirmed leadership could affect litigation.

"It does complicate some things when it comes to such issues as who needs to sign off on rules, who needs to sign off on policies, questions around proper succession, proper exercise of authority, and occasionally those things can trip people up in litigation if it's not properly done," he remarked.

+ HOLLAND & KNIGHT LLP TRUMP COLLEGE-ATHLETE MANDATE SEEKS DOL INPUT AMID CASES

Labor and employment attorney Timothy Taylor was quoted in a Law360 article on President Donald Trump's executive order directing the U.S. Department of Labor (DOL) to issue guidance on the employment status of college athletes. Per the order, titled "Saving College Sports," Labor Secretary Lori Chavez-DeRemer and the National Labor Relations Board (NLRB) will "clarify the status of collegiate athletes" in terms of classifying them as employees or non-employees. The order comes as courts have issued various rulings on the matter, including a 2021 U.S. Supreme Court decision that struck down NCAA rules restricting education-related compensation and benefits for student-athletes. Mr. Taylor explained the guidance will likely come from the DOL's Wage and Hour Division and could take one of several forms: informal guidance documents, opinion letters or an administrator's interpretation, in addition to amicus briefs in litigation. Another option, he said, is updating the division's field operations handbook, an internal manual containing agency statutory interpretations.

+ HOLLAND & KNIGHT LLP WATERFRONT BUILDING OFFERS HIGH DEMAND, BUT COMPLEX REVIEW

Land use and zoning attorney Kyrus Lamont Freeman was interviewed for a Law360 article examining the challenges surrounding waterfront development. The multifaceted nature of these properties - a natural resource also used for recreation, transport and commerce - raises a host of issues, from environmental considerations to ownership rights to public access. Mr. Freeman noted that in addition to local zoning and building codes, federal environmental reviews from the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) or U.S. Army Corps of Engineers can also enter the picture. He added that developers should determine whether a property is located in a special zone, such as a nature conservation area or historic preservation district, which would implicate another level of permitting, paperwork and balancing multiple jurisdictional requirements. Overall, he emphasized the importance of working with a multidisciplinary legal team to shepherd a project through its entire life cycle, from the initial proposals to groundbreaking to grand opening.

"You've got to have the wherewithal, the experience, the ability to get a good team - a good legal team, if you're in a jurisdiction that requires lobbying, then a good lobbying team, a good architecture team, a good environmental team. A good team to figure out how to navigate the process, because the process can be tough," he commented.

August 06: Akin Gump Strauss Hauer Feld LLP: Patent Damages Based on Avoided Costs Do Not Invoke the Entire Market Value Rule

In ruling on a recent motion to strike, a judge in the Eastern District of Texas permitted a damages expert to rely on a damages theory based on defendant's "avoided costs," holding that this theory did not run afoul of the "entire market value rule."

When a product accused of infringement includes both the patented feature and other, non-patented features, the general rule is that royalties must be based not on the entire product, but rather on the "smallest saleable patent-practicing unit." This rule is derived from a concern that calculating a royalty based on the entire product will improperly compensate the patentee for non-infringing components. The entire market value rule provides a limited exception, however, allowing royalties to be based on revenue or profits for the entire product where the patentee proves that the patented feature drives demand for the entire product.

In this particular case, the patented technology concerned wireless telephone technology, and the smallest saleable practicing patent unit was the actual devices that practice the asserted patents. Plaintiff's damages expert, though, did not base his opinion on the revenue from those devices. Instead, Plaintiff argued that the patented technology allows wireless carriers to avoid the purchase and use of additional spectrum and based its damages theory on a variety of large financial figures, including the revenue and costs associated with the FCC auctions and secondary market sales of spectrum, the total value of the defendant's spectrum holdings, and the total spectrum saved due to the asserted patents.

+ KIRKLAND & ELLIS: WIRECARD: GERMAN DISTRICT COURT RULES DOUBLE-DIP STRUCTURE IS ENFORCEABLE

The Munich District Court in July delivered a first-instance verdict in the Wirecard insolvency,1 allowing holders of convertible notes issued by a Wirecard subsidiary and guaranteed by Wirecard to ultimately recover under two separate claims against the estate (double-dip).

Such double-dip structures (and similar) have a long legacy in corporate financing transactions and have become particularly topical in the context of liability management transactions as a tool to maximise creditors' recoveries by establishing multiple independent claims against the same pool of collateral assets. Double-dip financings can be used to raise new money, address maturities and reduce interest expense; the structure can incentivise creditor participation, given participating creditors receive "two bites at the apple" without technically priming existing creditors.

+ KIRKLAND & ELLIS: WIRECARD: GERMAN DISTRICT COURT RULES DOUBLE-DIP STRUCTURE IS ENFORCEABLE

The Munich District Court in July delivered a first-instance verdict in the Wirecard insolvency,1 allowing holders of convertible notes issued by a Wirecard subsidiary and guaranteed by Wirecard to ultimately recover under two separate claims against the estate (double-dip).

Such double-dip structures (and similar) have a long legacy in corporate financing transactions and have become particularly topical in the context of liability management transactions as a tool to maximise creditors' recoveries by establishing multiple independent claims against the same pool of collateral assets. Double-dip financings can be used to raise new money, address maturities and reduce interest expense; the structure can incentivise creditor participation, given participating creditors receive "two bites at the apple" without technically priming existing creditors.

WASHINGTON, D.C. (August 11, 2025) - Tax attorney Andrew Siracuse has joined Holland & Knight's Washington, D.C., office as a partner in the Public Policy & Regulation Group. Previously, he spent nearly two decades with U.S. Sen. John Cornyn (R-Texas), a senior member of the Finance Committee and former Republican Whip, where he served as senior tax counsel and actively worked on policy related to appropriations, the federal budget, taxation, banking, insurance, retirement, pensions and Senate procedure.

"In the next few years, new tax rules will be written as a result of the One Big Beautiful Bill Act (OBBBA). Andrew's arrival significantly strengthens our extremely busy tax team at this crucial moment," said Rich Gold, the leader of Holland & Knight's Public Policy & Regulation Group. "His deep understanding of tax policy, along with his vast network of legislative and executive contacts, will be invaluable to current and future clients during the rulemaking process and beyond."

Norm Coleman (R-Minn.), a budget and tax analyst for the U.S. Senate Budget Committee and a legislative correspondent for Sen. Charles Grassley (R-Iowa). + HOLLAND & KNIGHT LLP PUNCHING IN: TRUMP'S LABOR DEPARTMENT PICKS AWAIT SENATE'S RETURN

Labor and employment attorney Timothy Taylor was highlighted in a Blooomberg Law article providing an update on the status of nominations for positions at the U.S. Department of Labor (DOL). The U.S. Senate must approve the nominees for DOL leadership roles such as the Solicitor of Labor and Wage and Hour Division leader, and most of the 10 slots have yet to be brought to the floor for a vote. Mr. Taylor noted that though the agency can continue pushing forth policy positions and proposing or rescinding rules, lacking confirmed leadership could affect litigation.

"It does complicate some things when it comes to such issues as who needs to sign off on rules, who needs to sign off on policies, questions around proper succession, proper exercise of authority, and occasionally those things can trip people up in litigation if it's not properly done," he remarked.

Source: Company Website

+ HOLLAND & KNIGHT LLP TRUMP COLLEGE-ATHLETE MANDATE SEEKS DOL INPUT AMID CASES

Labor and employment attorney Timothy Taylor was quoted in a Law360 article on President Donald Trump's executive order directing the U.S. Department of Labor (DOL) to issue guidance on the employment status of college athletes. Per the order, titled "Saving College Sports," Labor Secretary Lori Chavez-DeRemer and the National Labor Relations Board (NLRB) will "clarify the status of collegiate athletes" in terms of classifying them as employees or non-employees. The order comes as courts have issued various rulings on the matter, including a 2021 U.S. Supreme Court decision that struck down NCAA rules restricting education-related compensation and benefits for student-athletes. Mr. Taylor explained the guidance will likely come from the DOL's Wage and Hour Division and could take one of several forms: informal guidance documents, opinion letters or an administrator's interpretation, in addition to amicus briefs in litigation. Another option, he said, is updating the division's field operations handbook, an internal manual containing agency statutory interpretations.

Source: Company Website

+ HOLLAND & KNIGHT LLP WATERFRONT BUILDING OFFERS HIGH DEMAND, BUT COMPLEX REVIEW

Land use and zoning attorney Kyrus Lamont Freeman was interviewed for a Law360 article examining the challenges surrounding waterfront development. The multifaceted nature of these properties - a natural resource also used for recreation, transport and commerce - raises a host of issues, from environmental considerations to ownership rights to public access. Mr. Freeman noted that in addition to local zoning and building codes, federal environmental reviews from the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) or U.S. Army Corps of Engineers can also enter the picture. He added that developers should determine whether a property is located in a special zone, such as a nature conservation area or historic preservation district, which would implicate another level of permitting, paperwork and balancing multiple jurisdictional requirements. Overall, he emphasized the importance of working with a multidisciplinary legal team to shepherd a project through its entire life cycle, from the initial proposals to groundbreaking to grand opening.

"You've got to have the wherewithal, the experience, the ability to get a good team - a good legal team, if you're in a jurisdiction that requires lobbying, then a good lobbying team, a good architecture team, a good environmental team. A good team to figure out how to navigate the process, because the process can be tough," he commented.

August 07: Akin Gump Strauss Hauer Feld LLP: FinCEN Issues Order Delaying Effective Date of Investment Adviser Rule

Following an earlier announcement on July 21, 2025, the U.S. Department of the Treasury's Financial Crimes Enforcement Network ("FinCEN"), on August 5, 2025, issued an Exemptive Relief Order ("Order") to delay for two years, from January 1, 2026 to January 1, 2028, the effective date of the final rule Anti-Money Laundering/Countering the Financing of Terrorism Program and Suspicious Activity Report Filing Requirements for Registered Investment Advisers and Exempt Reporting Advisers (the "Investment Adviser Rule"). FinCEN, in its earlier announcement, indicated its intent to "revisit the substance" of the Investment Adviser Rule through a future rulemaking process. FinCEN has, in the latest Order, indicated it intends to review the Investment Adviser Rule to "ensure it strikes an appropriate balance between cost and benefit," is consistent with the Trump administration's "deregulatory agenda" and is "effectively tailored to the diverse business models and risk profiles of the investment adviser sector." FinCEN indicated in the Order its intent to propose, through a rulemaking process, a new effective date for the Investment Adviser Rule no earlier than January 1, 2028. August 06: Akin Gump Strauss Hauer Feld LLP: Patent Damages Based on Avoided Costs Do Not Invoke the Entire Market Value Rule

In ruling on a recent motion to strike, a judge in the Eastern District of Texas permitted a damages expert to rely on a damages theory based on defendant's "avoided costs," holding that this theory did not run afoul of the "entire market value rule."

When a product accused of infringement includes both the patented feature and other, non-patented features, the general rule is that royalties must be based not on the entire product, but rather on the "smallest saleable patent-practicing unit." This rule is derived from a concern that calculating a royalty based on the entire product will improperly compensate the patentee for non-infringing components. The entire market value rule provides a limited exception, however, allowing royalties to be based on revenue or profits for the entire product where the patentee proves that the patented feature drives demand for the entire product.

In this particular case, the patented technology concerned wireless telephone technology, and the smallest saleable practicing patent unit was the actual devices that practice the asserted patents. Plaintiff's damages expert, though, did not base his opinion on the revenue from those devices. Instead, Plaintiff argued that the patented technology allows wireless carriers to avoid the purchase and use of additional spectrum and based its damages theory on a variety of large financial figures, including the revenue and costs associated with the FCC auctions and secondary market sales of spectrum, the total value of the defendant's spectrum holdings, and the total spectrum saved due to the asserted patents.

August 06: Akin Gump Strauss Hauer Feld LLP: Timeline of Effective Dates of Health Care Provisions of OBBBA is Key to Understanding Impacts

Over 35 health care provisions were included in the One Big Beautiful Bill Act of 2025. These provisions span Medicaid, the Children's Health Insurance Program (CHIP), the Affordable Care Act (ACA) marketplaces, Medicare and commercial insurance. The majority of provisions alter eligibility and spending for health care coverage under Medicaid - and take effect over the next three years. All health provisions of OBBBA will have notable impacts on coverage and care delivery in the U.S. when they take effect. The timeline of effective dates, presented in this Alert, are essential to understanding the cost and coverage impacts.

To comply with the law, states will need to build and operate numerous additional Medicaid and ACA eligibility checks and systems by certain deadlines. Adults who live in states that have expanded Medicaid coverage under the ACA will face narrowed eligibility for Medicaid, and they may need to report monthly their hours of work or community engagement to maintain Medicaid coverage when their state implements this provision. Children of these adults could retain Medicaid eligibility separately - and need to take steps to remain enrolled.
